questions.question_text: A project facilitator is working within a large project team that includes 36 members representing different organizational groups. The current communications plan calls for full status updates to be emailed to the whole group twice per week. Which of the following factors should be considered FIRST when communicating with this group?

choices.B: The large team may be dispersed over different time zones, preventing the team from receiving the status updates at the same time.
choices.A: Providing all parties with frequent updates keeps the team on the same page as the project moves forward.
choices.D: All team members receive the same level of detail, ensuring the accuracy of the status updates
choices.C: The frequency, method, and level of detail provided should be different for each target audience.

discussion.content: I'm honestly thinking it's B. The large group may be dispersed with different time zones. It already states that ALL will receive the SAME amount of detail in the status reports.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A Pareto chart is a visual tool that helps identify the most significant factors contributing to a problem. It displays the relative frequency or size of each issue in descending order of importance, allowing project managers to prioritize their actions.

A Pareto chart is a tool that's primarily used for taking preventive action.

Preventive action is focused on identifying and addressing the root causes of problems to prevent them from occurring in the first place. In contrast, corrective action is focused on addressing the symptoms of problems that have already occurred.

In this case, the Pareto chart is being used to identify the most significant factors contributing to the project's problems. By identifying the root causes of these issues, the project manager can take preventive action to address them and reduce the overall number of problems. This approach is more effective than simply taking corrective action to address the symptoms of the problems without addressing their underlying causes.

questions.question_text: A project team has just finished one phase of product development and is gathering requirements for the next phase. Which of the following methodologies is being applied?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I'm going to agree with the given answer, and here's why. The question states the team has "finished" a phase, and it's gathering information for the next phase. You can assume that they have been using this methodology of Completing a phase> gathering information on a phase> starting phase> completing phase> repeat. These are the characteristics of a waterfall model.
